DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Sets Up Noriega Hot Line
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department set up a hot line today to collect tips from callers who may have information on the whereabouts of deposed Panamanian leader Manuel Antonio Noriega. The Bush administration is offering a $1 million reward for information leading to the capture of Noriega, who is wanted by federal authorities on drug trafficking charges. The line was set up after the White House and the Justice Department received calls from people offering information about Noriega, who has been missing since U.S. forces invaded Panama early Tuesday, said department spokesman David Runkel. Information taken from people who call the number will be forwarded to U.S. officials in Panama. The U.S. Embassy in Panama City is collecting tips from Panamanians, Runkel said. Runkel cited a number of calls already received when asked if he thought the Justice Department realistically expected to get useful information about Noriega from people in this country. The spokesman said he couldn't say whether the tips in hand contained specific, credible or even useful information. One of the stated purposes of the invasion was to capture Noriega, but he has so far eluded capture. The hot line number is 202-633-1000.
